contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox Sailboat Specifications |image = Finn dinghy.svg |caption = |class_image = Finn black.svg |crew = 1 |loa = {{convert|4.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |lwl = {{convert|4.34|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |beam = {{convert|1.47|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |draft = {{convert|0.17|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |hull = {{convert|107|kg|abbr=on}} |mastheight = {{convert|6.66|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |mainsail = {{convert|10.6|m2|abbr=on}} |d-pn = 90.1<ref name="UScb">{{cite web |url=http://offshore.ussailing.org/Portsmouth_Yardstick/Current_Tables/Centerboard_Classes.htm |title=Centerboard Classes |publisher=US Sailing |accessdate=31 July 2012}}</ref> |rya-pn = 1060<ref name="RYA2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.rya.org.uk/SiteCollectionDocuments/technical/Web%20Documents/py-general/2012%20listv3.xls |title=Portsmouth Number List 2012 |publisher=Royal Yachting Association |accessdate=31 July 2012}}</ref> |phrf = |updated = 13 Aug 2012 [http://www.finnclass.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=60&Itemid=51] |olympic = current }} The '''Finn''' dinghy is the men's single-handed, [[cat-rigged]] [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] class for [[sailing]]. It was designed by Swedish canoe designer, [[Rickard Sarby]], in 1949 for the [[1952 Summer Olympics]] in [[Helsinki]]. Since the 1952 debut of the boat, the design has been in every summer Olympics, making it one of the most prolific Olympic sailboats. ==Design Changes== [[Image:Finn dinghies in Karrebæksminde 2.jpg|thumb|160px|left|Finn dinghies]] [[Image:Søren Svare i Jolle.JPG|thumb|160px|right|Finn dinghy]] Although the Finn [[hull (watercraft)|hull]] has changed little since 1949, there have been developments to the [[Rigging|rig]]. The original [[Mast (sailing)|spars]] were made of wood until the late 60’s and early 70’s when there was a slow change to aluminum masts. Aluminum is significantly more flexible and gives more control over sail shape. It became common place after the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in [[Munich]] when they were first supplied to Olympic sailors. Recently, carbon fiber masts have become common place in competitive Finn fleets. The sails too have gone through revolution and are now commonly made of [[Kevlar]]. {{-}} ==Events== ===Olympic Games=== * [[List_of_Olympic_medalists_in_sailing#Finn_class|Olympic medalists]] ===Open World Championships=== {{see also|Finn World Championships}} The '''Finn Gold cup''' recognised as the World Championship for the Finn class [[International Sailing Federation]] ===Junior World Championship=== {{expand section|date=April 2012}} ===Master World Championship=== {{expand section|date=April 2012}} ===Continental Championships=== * [[2006 Finn Open European Championship]] ==References== <references /> ==External links== {{Commons category|Finn (dinghy)}} * [http://www.finnclass.org/ International Finn Association] * [http://www.nafinnclass.org/ North American Finn Class for US and Canada] * [http://www.finn-dinghy.de/ Finn Site - Germany] * [http://www.finnargentina.blogspot.com/ Finn BLOG - Argentina] * [http://www.finnargentina.8k.com/ Finn Site - Argentina] * [http://www.finnclass.cz Finn Association Czech Republic] * [http://www.sailing.org/classes/FINN.php ISAF Finn Microsite] {{International Sailing Federation Classes}} {{Olympic Games Sailing}} {{Olympic class sailboats}} {{International Dinghies}} {{Sailing dinghies and skiffs}} [[Category:Classes of the International Sailing Federation]] [[Category:Dinghies]] [[Category:Olympic sailboat classes]]
